params.note: Alternative methods for generating hPSC-derived iNPCs include transient induction through mesoderm lineages, direct reprogramming from fibroblasts, or short-term expansion (up to 14 days). This protocol enables stable expansion of hPSC-derived iNPCs for months with 90–95% SIX2+ purity and retained nephrogenic potential.
Transcriptome analysis shows hNPSR-v2-cultured iNPCs better resemble primary human NPCs in vivo compared to transient iNPCs.
iNPC-derived nephron organoids show minimal off-target cell types and increased maturity, including COL4A3+/COL4A4+ podocytes, compared to hPSC-derived organoids.
Improved iNPC specification enhances proximal tubule segmentation and maturity, consistent with higher-quality NPCs generating more mature nephrons.
This protocol enables genome-wide CRISPR screens in human iNPCs to identify regulators of self-renewal with implications for congenital kidney disease and Wilms tumor.
Genome editing can be performed directly in iNPC lines; e.g., PKD2−/− iNPCs generate cystic nephron organoids recapitulating polycystic kidney disease.
hNPSR-v2 medium reprograms hPSC-derived or primary human fetal podocytes to an NPC-like state, revealing podocyte plasticity.
iNPC-derived nephron organoids show higher expression of mature podocyte markers (COL4A3, COL4A4) than hPSC-derived organoids, offering a tool to model glomerular diseases.
Limitations: iNPC-derived nephron organoids lack vascularization, preventing modeling of glomerular filtration; slit diaphragm formation remains unconfirmed.
Cultured iNPCs resemble primary human NPCs in gene expression and developmental potential but exhibit some differences.
